chapters.name: Tan Family
chapters.details:
My name is Stewart Tan born in Sungei Pelek in 1954 July 28. My wife is Doreen  Tay (dob 04/12/57) . Both of us are retirees now leading a carefree and peaceful life. We have been traveling quite a lot since retirement to Japan, China , Taiwan , Malaysia, Germany etc to explore the wonders of God’s creation.
I have three sons Calvin Tan , Jason Tan and Derek tan .My eldest son, Calvin Tan Ming Hao (dob 30/7/89) is married to Yuki (dob 2/10/92), and they both work as engineers in Munich. Both graduated with master in engineering from Esslingen University in Germany.  Despite the geographical distance between us, we make an effort to stay connected with Calvin and his family. We call each other occasionally, and either my wife and I visit them in Germany, or they come back to Singapore once a year. These visits are precious moments for us, as they allow us to maintain our bond and catch up on each other's lives.  One of the most memorable moments came when my first grandson, Kento, was born in Munich .  
My second son is Jason (dob 24/9/92). His wife is Sarine Zou (dob 19/4/94)), Both graduated from Cambridge University Uk . He had been working a few years in London as Data Scientist. In mid 2023 both relocate back to Singapore . Sarine  is an Assistant Professor in  a local university  specialising in Accounting. We are happy for both of them as we can visit them more often .    
My third son is Derek (dob 30/9/95) .His wife is Isabelle Kong (dob 13/11/97) . Both graduated from the University of Michigan USA and returned  to Singapore during covid period 2020. Derek specialised in Engineering and IT and now working as a robotic engineer . His wife majored in IT and working in government agency . We are also happy to see them often .  

Our children success in their  career and their strong family values are a testament to the importance of education and hard work that my wife and I have instilled in our children. We have always encouraged them to excel in their education and supported them financially and emotionally. It is heartwarming to see that they  have embraced these values and applied them in his life. This tradition helps us maintain a close relationship with all our children and ensures that we remain a united and supportive family. 
In conclusion, the relationship between my children are one of love, pride, and support. We cherish the time we spend together and the bond we share. Our family values and traditions have played a significant role in shaping the successful and respectful individuals that our children have become.









Our children success in their  career and their strong family values are a testament to the importance of education and hard work that my wife and I have instilled in our children. We have always encouraged them to excel in their education and supported them financially and emotionally. It is heartwarming to see that they  have embraced these values and applied them in his life. This tradition helps us maintain a close relationship with all our children and ensures that we remain a united and supportive family. 
In conclusion, the relationship between my children are one of love, pride, and support. We cherish the time we spend together and the bond we share. Our family values and traditions have played a significant role in shaping the successful and respectful individuals that our children have become.

note: as time goes by , my memory will fade , so attaching the dob to each name will help me to celebrate their birthdays.

chapters.name: Grandson -Kento Tan
chapters.details:
My relationship with my grandson, Kento Tan, is incredibly special to me. Kento was born in Munich on December 6, 2021, and he is the son of my eldest child, Calvin Tan, and his wife, Yuki. . Kento's birth was a memorable moment for our entire family, and he is such a cute and adorable baby. I am blessed and give thanks to God for giving us such a pleasant family.

My wife, Tay Sek Goh, and I make an effort to stay connected with our children and grandchildren, despite the geographical distance between us.  In May 2022, my wife and I visited Munich for a month to spend time with Kento and his parents. It was a wonderful experience, and we cherished every moment we spent with our grandson. We are already planning our next visit to Munich in April 2024, and we are looking forward to spending more time with Kento and exploring the city together. During our visits to Munich, we enjoy sightseeing and experiencing the local attractions with our family. It's a great way for us to bond and create lasting memories together. We are excited to share these experiences with Kento as he grows older and can appreciate the beauty and history of Munich.  As grandparents, we are committed to supporting Kento and any future grandchildren in their endeavors, just as we have done for our own children. We believe that maintaining a strong family bond is essential, and we will continue to make an effort to stay connected with our loved ones, no matter the distance. As we face challenging times in life, all we can do is encourage each other and support our family members financially, emotionally, and mentally.  Becoming a grandparent has changed my perspective on family and life, making me realize the importance of cherishing every moment and staying connected with our loved ones.

chapters.name: Parents & Siblings
chapters.details:
My parents, Tan Seong Luan and Yew Poh Chaye, were the bedrock of my existence, the compass that guided me through life's tumultuous journey. Born in 1903 and 1921 respectively, they left their homeland of China and settled in Malaysia, where they faced the daunting task of raising ten children amidst the backdrop of the Japanese occupation. Their resilience in the face of adversity was nothing short of remarkable.

My father, a man of unwavering strength and determination, was a strict disciplinarian who knew the value of hard work and the importance of investing in land for our rubber plantation. His teachings on perseverance have been etched into my very being. My mother, on the other hand, was the embodiment of kindness and warmth. Her smile was a constant, even during the hardest of times, and her ability to maintain a positive outlook has greatly influenced how I approach life and my relationships with others.

Despite their financial struggles, my parents ensured that we never went hungry, sometimes borrowing from neighbors to provide for us. They were farmers, tapping rubber and rearing pigs, and through their labor, they instilled in us the values of strength and independence. Education was their beacon of hope for us, a tool they believed would pave the way to a better life.

Their sacrifices were not in vain. I was fortunate enough to complete my higher education in the UK, a dream that was made possible through their efforts and support. This experience has been a cornerstone of my life, shaping my worldview and the manner in which I raised my own children. I have always emphasized the importance of education to my sons, and it fills me with pride to see them as graduates from overseas universities, their horizons broadened by their experiences just as mine were.

The culinary traditions of my family are a testament to my parents' legacy. My favorite dishes to cook—red wine chicken, sweet sour spicy fish maw, and black pork—are more than just meals; they are cherished recipes passed down through generations. These dishes are the highlight of our festive occasions, a time when the family comes together to celebrate and remember the values my parents taught us.

My father, Tan Seong Luan, and my mother, Yew Poh Chaye, have indeed left an indelible mark on my life. Their legacy is not just in the lessons of hard work, perseverance, and the value of education, but also in the joy of cooking and the importance of family traditions. As I continue to navigate through life, I carry their teachings with me, a beacon that lights my way. I am eternally grateful for their guidance and the love they showered upon me. It is my hope to honor their memory by passing on these invaluable lessons to future generations, ensuring that their strength and resilience live on.

chapters.name: Brothers And Sisters
chapters.details:
Growing up in Sungei Pelek, my brothers and sisters were my closest companions. With two brothers and seven sisters, our home was a lively place, filled with laughter, love, and the occasional squabble. Life was tough, but facing challenges together forged an unbreakable bond among us. Our small farm, where we tapped rubber and raised pigs and chickens, taught us the value of hard work and teamwork. Those lessons have stayed with me throughout my life.

I often think back to our wooden house, where we all lived under one roof. It was a sanctuary of comfort, where we shared chores, dreams, and countless meals. My sisters, exceptional cooks, passed down their culinary skills to me. These shared moments in the kitchen created lasting memories that I carry with me to this day.

As we grew older, life took us in different directions. Some of my siblings moved to Malaysia and Singapore, starting their own families. It was bittersweet to see us drift apart, yet the love we shared remained a constant in my life. I cherish the times we gathered, reminiscing about our childhood and the adventures we had. Those moments filled my heart with warmth, reminding me of the strength of our family ties.

Looking back, I realize how much I treasure my siblings. Now, in our 70s and 80s, we are aware of the passage of time. My eldest sister is almost 87, while my youngest brother is around 65. Each visit to Malaysia is a journey to reconnect with them. I make it a point to go from house to house, saying hello and keeping in touch. It's important to me because we share a legacy—a bond of love and warmth that is irreplaceable.

When I published "Memories from Our Family Tree," it was more than just preserving our history—it was about maintaining the connections between us. The book became a bridge that helped us stay connected despite the physical distance between us. I distributed 30 copies to all my brothers and sisters, and their joy upon receiving it during my last visit to Malaysia was heartwarming.

As we age, our bond remains strong, a testament to the love we have nurtured over the years. My siblings and I have grown closer, especially as time goes by. Whenever they are free, I encourage them to open the book and look at the photos, using it as a way to remember and stay connected with each other. I always remind them that when they feel lonely, they should reach out and give each other a call. Though some of us are far apart and less mobile now, these small gestures help maintain our connection.

Family is truly the heart of who we are. My brothers and sisters have shaped my life in ways I can't fully express. I carry that love with me always, and it continues to inspire my journey through life.

chapters.name: Children
chapters.details:
Children have always been at the heart of my life's journey, weaving a tapestry of joy, hope, and familial connection. From my early days at the Methodist English school to the warm pews of the Methodist church in Sungei Pelek, the teachings of Jesus, particularly the call to love our neighbors, have guided my path. I fondly remember quoting John 3:16, a verse that resonated deeply with the young hearts around me, encapsulating the essence of Christian belief.

Reflecting on my mission trip to Batam, Indonesia, I recall the profound impact it had on me. The children there, living in poverty yet radiating hope, reminded me of life's fragility and the eternal promise that awaits us all. Sharing my faith has never been easy, but inviting others to church and gospel services has been my way of connecting with children and the broader community, bridging gaps with love and understanding.

My own children are a constant source of joy, despite the demands of their work. Their appreciation for the dishes I prepare—like the sweet and sour fish maw with sea cucumber during festive occasions or the beloved black belly pork—speaks to our shared heritage and the unspoken bond we cherish. These culinary traditions, passed down from my parents, are a testament to our family's enduring connection.

In my quieter moments, I dream of returning to baking, a hobby I seldom indulge in nowadays. The unbaked cheesecake, a particular favorite, is something I look forward to making again for someone who enjoys it as much as I do. It's a simple joy, much like the joy I find in the company of children, that I eagerly anticipate sharing once more.

The importance of family connections inspired me to write my book, "Memories from Our Family Tree." With ten brothers and sisters, scattered across Malaysia and Singapore, each with their own children and grandchildren, I wanted to create a legacy for future generations. This book serves as a bridge, allowing our children to know each other, fostering an understanding of who is who in each family.

The project seemed daunting at first, but with the help of my nieces and nephews, we gathered photos and stories from each family. My number one sister's family alone includes around 30 children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. It was a rewarding challenge to compile these memories, ensuring that each family is represented, allowing others to see and understand their extended family.

As I reflect on these experiences, I am filled with gratitude. I thank God for blessing us with obedient children, a grandchild, and lovely daughters-in-law. His abundant protection, provision, and blessings have been a constant in our lives. These connections, whether through faith, food, or family history, are the threads that bind us, creating a rich tapestry of love and shared memories.

In the end, it is the children—my own, those I've encountered, and those who will come after us—who inspire me to continue weaving this tapestry. Their laughter, curiosity, and the promise of the future they hold are the reasons I cherish these moments and strive to preserve the legacy of our family for generations to come.

chapters.name: Sungei Pelek
chapters.details:
Sungei Pelek, my birthplace, holds a special place in my heart. Nestled in the state of Selangor, Malaysia, this small town, just a short drive from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, is where my journey began. The name itself, derived from the Malay word “sungei” meaning “river,” speaks to the natural beauty and serenity that surrounded my childhood home. Growing up in Sungei Pelek, I was part of a large family, with two brothers and seven sisters, living together in a modest wooden house with just five rooms. Life was not easy; our family made ends meet through farming, tapping rubber, and raising pigs and chickens. Despite the challenges, these experiences instilled in us a strong work ethic and a sense of responsibility towards our community.

The community in Sungei Pelek was like an extended family. Everyone knew everyone, and any event, whether a wedding or a funeral, involved the whole village. This sense of unity and togetherness was a defining feature of my childhood, shaping my values and relationships as I grew older. I remember walking 500 meters to school every day, a journey that was always filled with laughter and chatter with friends from different races and backgrounds. These interactions taught me the importance of diversity and acceptance, lessons that have stayed with me throughout my life.

Our neighborhood was a tapestry of beliefs, with my family being one of the few Christian families in town. We respected each other's traditions, and during Christmas, we would go caroling from house to house, sharing the joy of the season with our Buddhist neighbors. This mutual respect and celebration of different cultures enriched our lives and deepened my appreciation for the diverse world we live in. Chinese New Year was another highlight of our year, as the entire village came alive with decorations, new clothes, and the exchange of angpows, those cherished red packets filled with money. These celebrations were more than just festive occasions; they were opportunities to strengthen bonds and create lasting memories with family and neighbors.

My Christian upbringing played a significant role in shaping my worldview. Attending the Methodist English school and participating in the children's Sunday service at the Methodist church in Sungei Pelek taught me the values of love and service. The teachings of Jesus, especially the Bible verse John 3:16, have been a source of inspiration and guidance throughout my life. I learned that life is fleeting, and one day we will meet God in heaven. Sharing our beliefs with others can be challenging, but inviting them to church or gospel services is a step towards bridging that gap.

After completing my secondary education, I left Sungei Pelek to pursue higher studies at Tunku Abdul Rahman College in Kuala Lumpur and later at the University of Lancaster in Britain. These experiences broadened my horizons and set the course for my career in finance. Yet, no matter where I went, Sungei Pelek remained a constant in my heart. I make it a point to visit twice a year, reconnecting with the roots and community that have shaped me into who I am today. Each visit is a journey back to my past, a reminder of the values of togetherness, unity, and respect for different beliefs that continue to guide my life.

One of my most cherished memories is a photograph of our old house in Sungei Pelek, a tangible link to the place where it all began. The house, though simple and humble, was filled with love and laughter, a testament to the resilience and strength of my family. It stands as a symbol of the life lessons learned and the bonds forged in this small town.

Sungei Pelek taught me that community is not just about living in proximity to others but about sharing lives, supporting each other, and celebrating diversity. It is a place where traditions are honored, and differences are embraced, a microcosm of the world I strive to create in my own life. As I reflect on my journey, I am grateful for the foundation that Sungei Pelek provided, a foundation built on love, faith, and community.

My Christian upbringing played a significant role in shaping my worldview. Attending the Methodist English school and participating in the children's Sunday service at the Methodist church in Sungei Pelek taught me the values of love and service. The teachings of Jesus, especially the Bible verse John 3:16, have been a source of inspiration and guidance throughout my life. I learned that life is fleeting, and one day we will meet God in heaven. Sharing our beliefs with others can be challenging, but inviting them to church or gospel services is a step towards bridging that gap.

After completing my secondary education, I left Sungei Pelek to pursue higher studies at Tunku Abdul Rahman College in Kuala Lumpur and later at the University of Lancaster in Britain. These experiences broadened my horizons and set the course for my career in finance. Yet, no matter where I went, Sungei Pelek remained a constant in my heart. I make it a point to visit twice a year, reconnecting with the roots and community that have shaped me into who I am today. Each visit is a journey back to my past, a reminder of the values of togetherness, unity, and respect for different beliefs that continue to guide my life.

One of my most cherished memories is a photograph of our old house in Sungei Pelek, a tangible link to the place where it all began. The house, though simple and humble, was filled with love and laughter, a testament to the resilience and strength of my family. It stands as a symbol of the life lessons learned and the bonds forged in this small town.

Sungei Pelek taught me that community is not just about living in proximity to others but about sharing lives, supporting each other, and celebrating diversity. It is a place where traditions are honored, and differences are embraced, a microcosm of the world I strive to create in my own life. As I reflect on my journey, I am grateful for the foundation that Sungei Pelek provided, a foundation built on love, faith, and community.

chapters.name: West Malaysia
chapters.details:
I was born in the small town of Sungei Pelek, nestled in the state of Selangor, West Malaysia. My early life there was marked by the simplicity of rural living, where my family's livelihood depended on the modest income from our farm. We tapped rubber and raised pigs and chickens, which were enough to sustain our daily needs. Despite the challenges of growing up in a poor family, the close-knit bond I shared with my two brothers and seven sisters in our wooden five-room house remains one of my most cherished memories.

West Malaysia, with its lush landscapes and agricultural opportunities, was the backdrop of my formative years. It was here that I learned the value of hard work and the importance of family. The experiences I had in Sungei Pelek laid the foundation for my future endeavors, including my career in accounting and later, my transition into real estate. West Malaysia will always hold a special place in my heart as the starting point of my life's journey.

chapters.name: Kuala Lumpur, Sabah , Singapore
chapters.details:
My relationship with Kuala Lumpur is one that has profoundly shaped my early life and career. It all began when I left the familiarity of my village to pursue higher education in accounting and finance at Tunku Abdul Rahman university . The city, with its bustling streets and towering skyscrapers, was a world away from the close-knit community I grew up in. Yet, it was here in this beautiful city that I took my first steps towards realizing my dreams.

In 1977, I started my professional journey as an accounts trainee at Coopers & Lybrand.. The knowledge and experience I gained there were invaluable, and it wasn't long before I transitioned to teaching accounting at Kinabalu Commercial College in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. This period was particularly enriching as it allowed me to connect with students and share the insights I had acquired.

After years in Kuala Lumpur and Sabah, I decided to relocate to Singapore, a beautiful city and land of opportunities. Shortly after my arrival, I found a job at Precision Watchcase Pte Ltd as an accountant . This experience was pivotal, as it broadened my understanding of the intricacies of manufacturing and international business.

It was in Singapore that I was inspired to further my education at the University of Lancaster in Britain, a decision that solidified my career in the accounting sector. The principles and skills I learned during that time have been a constant throughout my career. The city also sparked a significant change in my professional path.
Looking back on my journey, I am filled with gratitude for the opportunities and experiences that Kuala Lumpur , Sabah and Singapore have offered. It has been instrumental in shaping me into the person I am today, with a career that spans across different industries and roles.

chapters.name: University Of Lancaster
chapters.details:
My relationship with the University of Lancaster has been a cornerstone of my professional life since I embarked on my master's in accounting and finance back in 1983. The university, with its tranquil hilltop location 5km from the city center, provided a peaceful retreat where I could immerse myself in my studies and lay the groundwork for my future.

The lessons I learned within the walls of this esteemed institution have been a bedrock for my career in accounting. The knowledge and skills I acquired there have been directly applicable to my work, offering me a robust foundation that has supported me throughout my professional journey. The University of Lancaster was more than just an educational establishment; it was a forge where my career in finance and business was shaped.

As I reflect on my time at the university, I am filled with a sense of pride and a touch of nostalgia. The serene environment and the rigorous academic program were not just conducive to learning but also to personal development. It was here that I not only honed my academic prowess but also developed life skills that have been indispensable in my career trajectory.

 It is clear that the foundation laid at the University of Lancaster was instrumental in every step I took thereafter. The university's impact on my life is indelible, and I will forever hold dear the memories and experiences from those formative years on the beautiful, vast landscape of the campus.

chapters.name: Accounting
chapters.details:
My relationship with accounting is deeply rooted in my heritage and upbringing in the small town of Sungei Pelek, a place I still hold dear and visit during Chinese New Year and Qing Ming Festival each year. It was here, amidst the festivities of my early childhood, where I first became fascinated with managing angpows, a tradition that ignited my passion for financial management. This passion steered me towards a career in accounting, a profession held in high regard alongside engineering and medicine during my formative years.

My educational journey in Kuala Lumpur at Tunku Abdul Rahman College, followed by a Master's in Finance at the University of Lancaster in Britain, was more than just academic progression; it was a period of personal growth that shaped my worldview and professional ethos. In 1977, I embarked on my career as an accounts trainee at Coopers & Lybrand in Kuala Lumpur, where I earned a modest $120 monthly. Despite the low pay, the wealth of knowledge I gained in finalizing corporate accounts was invaluable.

I soon found joy in teaching accounting and computer studies at Kinabalu Commercial College, where I could impart my knowledge to aspiring students . By 1979, I had ventured into the role of an internal auditor with Hap Seng Group in Tawau, auditing timber camps across Sabah, often by helicopter—a unique and thrilling experience. The following year, I was headhunted by Goh Brothers, a housing developer, where I oversaw the accounts departmentand enjoyed a comfortable life.

In 1981, I returned to Singapore and joined Precision Watchcase Ltd as an accountant, handling the assembly of prestigious watch brands. This role, along with my subsequent position as a regional accountant with APV Singapore until 1988, allowed me to travel across various Asian countries, auditing their accounts and further honing my expertise. However, after years in accounting, I was drawn to the real estate industry, prompted by friends' invitations. This new chapter, which I embarked on before retiring in 2020, was carefree and exciting. 
Throughout my career, the principles of accounting have been a guiding force, enabling me to manage not only business finances but also my personal ones.

chapters.name: Real Estate Industry
chapters.details:
My journey with the real estate industry began after many years of working in various accounting roles. However, in the late 1980s, I decided to switch professions and join the real estate industry, thanks to an invitation from some friends.

Life in the real estate industry was carefree and exciting. I found that my background in accounting and finance proved to be incredibly valuable in this new field. This skillset, combined with my passion for the industry, made my transition into real estate a smooth one.

To further enhance my knowledge and skills in the real estate market, I attended courses that taught me the right tactics and timing. In Singapore, investing in good locations is crucial, and as a real estate agent, I was able to advise clients and make money for them too. This led to many clients becoming friends, and their continued trust in me helped me grow more confident in my abilities.

One of the most memorable moments during my time in the real estate industry was my ability to invest in properties during bad times and sell during good times. This strategy allowed me to make some money and reinvest it, giving me a great sense of achievement in life. My diverse career journey, from accounting to teaching and then to real estate, has shaped my skills and perspectives over the years, making me an all-rounder in the professional world.

A personal experience that stands out is when I bought a City Square Residences condominium because of its prime location and freehold status. It was easy to rent and has since appreciated  in value. The condominium is located near an MRT station and a shopping mall, making it an attractive investment. 

These client-turned-friend relationships had a significant impact on my life and career decisions. Some clients continued to recommend more clients to me, which helped my career as a realtor keep progressing. Building trust and confidence with my clients was essential for my personal growth and success in the real estate industry.

There were times when I had to handle challenging situations and calm clients down. I learned to use a soft approach and talk to them diplomatically. This wise approach made a huge difference in resolving conflicts and keeping deals on track. However, I also learned not to take things for granted. I once bought a property, and the lawyer forgot to exercise the contract on the due date, resulting in the deal being canceled. I should have been more alert by reminding her of the deadline. This experience taught me the importance of being proactive and vigilant in my dealings.

After this incident, I made sure to always check the deadlines of my deals and not rely on others, like lawyers, to inform me. This change in my approach helped me prevent similar issues in the future and ensured smoother transactions for my clients.

After many years in the real estate industry, I finally retired in 2020. Looking back, I am grateful for the experiences and opportunities that my career has provided me. The real estate industry has been an integral part of my life.  My final piece of advice in real estate is always to buy based on location, location, and location. You never go wrong. Don't listen to others blindly.

chapters.name: Hobbies
chapters.details:
Ever since my college days, I've had a strong connection with the gym. It's been a constant companion in my life, helping me stay fit and healthy. I'm grateful that our government encourages fitness by offering free gym entry for seniors like myself. This support has allowed me to maintain my interest in working out and staying active.

Swimming has also been a significant part of my life, starting from college and continuing until today. I find it to be an excellent way to stay fit and take care of my body. I believe that we must love our bodies, and going to the gym and swimming regularly are my ways of showing that love.

Living near a reservoir has been a blessing, as it provides a beautiful and breezy environment for jogging and brisk walks. I occasionally jog there, taking in the stunning sights and enjoying the calming atmosphere. The setting sun against the reservoir is a sight to behold, with the big red sun casting a warm glow over the water. The gentle blue waves and the cool breeze make me feel calm and relaxed, washing away any stress I might have.
After a jog, I often sit on a rock beside the water, close my eyes, and let the tranquility of the surroundings envelop me. It's moments like these that make me appreciate the beauty of nature and the importance of staying active and healthy.In conclusion, hobbies are important as they give us something to look forward to daily, whether we are still working or retired. They keep us fit and healthy, thus lessening the government's burden of caring for us. My relationship with the gym has been a significant part of my life, helping me stay fit, healthy, and focused on my goals. It's a place where I can unwind, relieve stress, and maintain a healthy lifestyle. I'm grateful for the opportunities I've had to stay active and the support I've received from my government and community. I hope to continue prioritizing my health and fitness, as well as serving others through my community work and faith. For those looking to discover new hobbies or interests, I would advise you to look for hobbies you are passionate about and spend more time to develop them. At the end of the day, you will find life is worth living.

chapters.name: Cooking & Baking
chapters.details:
Cooking and baking are the essence of my being, the threads that weave through the fabric of my life, binding together the rich tapestry of my family's history and traditions. In the sanctuary of my kitchen, I find solace and joy in the act of creating dishes that are a testament to our past and a beacon for our future. Each recipe, each ingredient tells a story—a narrative of where we've come from and the path we're paving forward.

My mother's red wine chicken, a dish vibrant in hue and rich in flavor, is a tradition I've proudly carried on since she passed away. The whole dish is red in color due to the rice wine, and the taste is simply awesome. It's cooked with chicken, garlic, ginger, sesame oil, sugar, and salt, and can be savored with rice or rice vermicelli. I remember the joy it brought during Chinese New Year when I was young, and now, I continue to cook it to keep the memory of my mother alive and to carry on the tradition she cherished.

My sisters, excellent cooks in their own right, shared their culinary wisdom with me, teaching me the ingredients and steps to create these beloved dishes. Though my siblings and I now have our individual homes, I cook for my family during festivals, and when friends come over, I prepare special dishes that are not easily available in restaurants. The sweet sour fish maw with sea cucumber is a second favorite, a dish that is very appetizing and often requested by my children and friends alike.

The black belly pork, with its tempting flavors of cinnamon, pepper, and garlic, is another family favorite that I've refined over the years. I've added my own twist by marinating it for a day to enhance the aroma, and sometimes, I'll add sliced yam to give the dish more volume, creating a hearty meal that's both satisfying and reminiscent of my parents' cooking.

My love for cheese naturally led me to baking cheesecakes, a delightful shift from the savory dishes I usually prepare. Whether unbaked or baked, these cheesecakes are a testament to my culinary artistry. The carrot cheesecake, with its white frosting and nuts, is a perfect example of my commitment to combining health with indulgence. The praise from an elderly lady at church, who called my carrot cheesecake the best she'd ever had, fills me with happiness and motivates me to continue experimenting with different toppings and seasonal fruits.

Cooking and baking are more than j ust preparing food; they are the heart of our family. The dishes I create are not just meals; they are the canvas upon which my family's history is painted, a culinary tapestry rich with tradition and flavor. My journey with food is deeply rooted in the heritage of the Chinese dialect group Fuzhou, from which many of my recipes originate. These dishes, with their succulent meats and rich spices, are narratives that have been passed down through generations.

The handwritten recipe on paper is more than mere instructions; it's a blueprint of our past and a promise for our future. Even as my children grow and their lives become too busy for cooking, their love for the dishes ensures that our culinary traditions will endure. The symbols on the recipe paper are not just ingredients and measurements; they represent the innovation intertwined with the tradition, a new chapter in our family's gastronomic saga.

In my kitchen, dish after dish, I paint the story of my family, a story of resilience, love, and the joy of home cooking. It's a joy as lasting and satisfying as the cheesecake itself, a symbol of my passion for blending tradition with my own unique flair. Cooking has always been a thread woven through the fabric of my life, a tradition that binds my family together and keeps our heritage alive. It's more than just a hobby for me; it's a way of honoring my parents and the memories we shared.

I remember the boat trips to visit my brother-in-law in Kapit, a time when river transport was the lifeline of our journeys. Those trips, now replaced by the convenience of highway transport, are cherished memories that remind me of the constant evolution of life. Just as the modes of travel have shifted, so too has my approach to cooking, always adapting and evolving, yet rooted in the traditions of my family.

Cooking is my connection to the past and a gift I share in the present. It's a legacy of love, flavor, and family that I will continue to cherish and pass down through the generations. Whether it's the red wine chicken that harkens back to festive Chinese New Year celebrations or the sweet sour fish maw with sea cucumber that tantalizes the taste buds of my guests, each dish is a chapter in my family's story, a story that I am honored to tell through the universal language of food.

I remember the boat trips to visit my brother-in-law in Kapit, a time when river transport was the lifeline of our journeys. Those trips, now replaced by the convenience of highway transport, are cherished memories that remind me of the constant evolution of life. Just as the modes of travel have shifted, so too has my approach to cooking, always adapting and evolving, yet rooted in the traditions of my family.

Cooking is my connection to the past and a gift I share in the present. It's a legacy of love, flavor, and family that I will continue to cherish and pass down through the generations. Whether it's the red wine chicken that harkens back to festive Chinese New Year celebrations or the sweet sour fish maw with sea cucumber that tantalizes the taste buds of my guests, each dish is a chapter in my family's story, a story that I am honored to tell through the universal language of food.

chapters.name: China
chapters.details:
China is not merely a country to me; it's a tapestry of my heritage, a reflection of my family's resilience, and a place that has profoundly shaped my worldview. My parents, Tan Seong Luan and Yew Poh Chaye, embarked on a journey from China to Malaysia in their youth, carrying with them the strength and determination that would later be the bedrock of our family. Despite the adversity they faced, including the Japanese occupation in Malaysia and the challenge of raising ten children in poverty, their unwavering love and tenacity were the greatest gifts they bestowed upon us.

The values of hard work, independence, and mutual support that my parents instilled in us have been my guiding principles. These values were further reinforced during my visit to China in September 2023, when I traveled to Harbin and Shenyang in the northeast. The cool autumn weather was a perfect backdrop for the exploration of these cities, rich in culture and history.

One of the most poignant experiences of my trip was a boat ride along the Yalu River in Dandong.As I glided across the waters, I was struck by the stark contrast between the two nations it separates. On one side, China's bright lights symbolized prosperity and progress, while on the other, the dimly lit landscape of North Korea served as a somber reminder of the disparities that exist in our world. This juxtaposition was not just a geographical observation but a moment of introspection about the fortunes of my own family and the opportunities we've been afforded.

Other memorable places were the Great Wall of China and visits to Sarine home in Zhuhai.
This journey to China was more than a trip; it was a pilgrimage to the roots of my family tree. It was a chance to walk the land of my ancestors, to breathe in the legacy they've passed down to me, and to witness firsthand the strength, resilience, and enduring power of family. China, with its vibrant history and its personal connection to my lineage, will always hold a significant place in my heart.

chapters.name: Japan
chapters.details: Travels have always been a significant part of my life, a source of joy and discovery that I hold dear. My journey to Japan, for instance, was an unforgettable experience. We toured central Japan, visiting bustling cities like Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, Kobe, and Takayama. But the most memorable place was Mount Fuji. It's a stunning, snow-capped mountain that stands as the tallest in Japan, and it's visible from the capital on clear days. The sight of it, with its peak covered in snow for five months of the year, is a cultural icon that evokes a sense of awe and wonder in me. Each travel experience, just like  the serene beauty of Mount Fuji  adds a new layer to my understanding of the world and its diverse cultures. These travels are not just trips; they are chapters in the story of my life, filled with rich experiences that I cherish and carry with me in my career and personal growth.

chapters.name: Taiwan
chapters.details:
My journey to Taiwan was an unforgettable chapter in my life, filled with thrilling adventures and fascinating discoveries. One of the highlights of my trip was visiting the National Palace Museum in Taipei. This museum houses a vast collection of rare artifacts, but the one that captivated me the most was the exquisite jadeite cabbage. This beautifully crafted piece, with its green leaves and white stem, dates back to the Qing dynasty (1644-1911) and is the only one of its kind on display. The jadeite cabbage has a rich history, having been brought to Taiwan by Chiang Kai-shek when he fled from communist China in 1949. It remains a significant artifact, attracting tourists from all over the globe.

Another memorable experience was my visit to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall. The hall, with its beautiful garden, is an excellent spot for cultural sightseeing. The large statue of Chiang Kai-shek adds to the historical significance of the place, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in Taiwan's history.

One of the most exhilarating moments of my trip was the ATV ride in Hualien. Riding along the beach, facing the vast Pacific Ocean, was a mix of adventure, fear, and excitement. It was my first time standing in front of the Pacific Ocean, and the sight of the pounding waves against the rocks was breathtaking. The ride was a thrilling experience, shared with a group of friends, making it even more enjoyable and memorable.

Hualien also offered a culinary delight with its fresh seafood. Dining at a restaurant facing the sea, I indulged in delicious dishes like abalone, octopus, and raw fish. The red Garoupa was particularly memorable, as I had never tasted fish from the Pacific Ocean before. The freshness and flavor of the seafood made it an unforgettable culinary experience.

Exploring the night markets was another highlight of my trip. The Taipei Ximending market, with its wide variety of food, was a feast for the senses. I particularly enjoyed the oyster mee sua, a fine vermicelli dish that was absolutely delicious. The pungent tofu, with its strong smell but great taste, was another interesting find. I also had the chance to try some juicy and sweet custard apples, which melted in my mouth. Taiwan is also famous for its pineapple tarts, which are sold all year round with beautiful packaging.

In conclusion, my trip to Taiwan was a tapestry of thrilling adventures, fascinating discoveries, and unforgettable experiences. From the jadeite cabbage at the National Palace Museum to the beautiful shores of Hualien, the delicious seafood, and the amazing street food at the night markets, Taiwan has left an indelible mark on my heart. I will always cherish the memories of my time spent in this beautiful country, and the experiences I had will forever remain vivid in my mind.

chapters.name: Other countries
chapters.details:
My life's journey has been a tapestry woven with threads from various countries, each strand representing a connection to a different part of the world. 

Germany - 
Munich, for instance, is not just a city in Germany to me; it's where my eldest son, Calvin Tan, his wife, Yuki and grandson kento , reside. This  city of picturesque landscapes, has deepened my bond with the place. The most memorable place I visited was the Neuschwanstein Castle with its   towers  and sit on the rugged hills . It is an iconic example of the Romantic style and remains a recognisable symbol of Bavaria and Germany.

Malaysia -Kota Kinabalu is a beautiful town where I spent a year as a teacher in Kinabalu Commercial College . It is a vibrant town with diverse cultures .

In Sarawak  I often visited Kapit, my wife’s hometown. The express boat trips along the river to Kapit were a tradition that remained unchanged until the recent development of a highway. While I may feel nostalgic for those boat trips, the convenience of the highway is undeniable, marking a significant shift in the local way of life.

America- The United States holds a special place in my heart as well. My third son, Derek Tan, and his wife, Isabelle Kong, both graduated from the University of Michigan. Visiting them allowed me to combine a family visit with witnessing the natural wonder of Niagara Falls. The white foam and green edges of the falls were quite vivid, and the emotions I felt witnessing Niagara Falls up close were indescribable. Two of the most memorable  places I visited were Harvard university and MIT. The buildings were majestic  and iconic . Though I do not have a chance to study there , at least I felt a sense of happiness of  being able to be there visiting and seeing all the bright students from all over the globe . Really proud and happy for them . 

Finland-In Finland, I had the extraordinary experience of visiting igloos. Although I never stayed overnight due to time constraints, sitting inside one for a while was beautiful, albeit cold. The igloos with glass roofs offered a glimpse into the serene yet harsh Arctic environment.



UK-
My relationship with Cambridge University is one that fills me with immense pride, not because I studied there, but because it's where my second son, Jason Tan and  his wife, Sarine Zhou . They graduated from this prestigious institution, and their time at Cambridge was a period of intense learning and growth.  I recalled my visit with a sense of nostalgia and admiration. It was not just the university's architecture that left an impression on me, but also the intellectual atmosphere that seemed to permeate every corner of the campus.

New Zealand-
During my visit to New Zealand, a place where sheep outnumber people, I was captivated by the pastoral beauty and the art of sheep shearing. The demonstration was a standout experience, showcasing the country's deep connection to sheep farming. I still remember the picturesque scene: a herd of sheep grazing with the majestic mountains in the backdrop, a memory so vivid I captured it in a photograph. The contrast of the white sheep against the mountain grandeur was striking, and I felt compelled to photograph them up close to capture the essence of New Zealand's countryside. New Zealand, with its lush landscapes and unique agricultural practices, left an indelible mark on me. The experience was unlike any other, and it stood in stark contrast to the urban vibrancy .
Hong Kong- 
It’s another beautiful bustling city which I never get tired to visit . Famous for their mouth-watering tim sum ,where I often miss the salted yolk custard buns.

chapters.name: Christian Belief
chapters.details:
My journey with Christian belief has been a lifelong adventure, deeply rooted in the warm memories of my childhood in Sungei Pelek. I grew up in a Christian family, and my faith was nurtured within the walls of a Methodist English primary school and the vibrant community of our local Methodist church. It was there, amidst the tales of Jesus' love and sacrifice, that my heart became intertwined with the teachings of Christ. I learned of a love so profound that it could forgive sins and offer the hope of an eternal life, a concept beautifully encapsulated in John 3:16, a verse that has become a cornerstone of my faith.

As I matured, the values Jesus taught—love for our neighbors and God, kindness, and humility—became the guiding principles of my life. I've been blessed with opportunities to participate in mission trips and outreach programs, such as the day trip to Batam, Indonesia. There, we visited a children's home, sharing the message of Jesus and distributing goodies to the children. Their smiles, so pure despite their hardships, were a testament to the transformative power of Jesus' love, a power I am committed to sharing with others.

My faith has been a beacon during life's storms, offering solace and strength. I recall a time when I was hospitalized for surgery, feeling anxious and uncertain. It was through prayer and the comfort of Philippians 4:6-7 that I found peace, and it was in the fellowship of Sunday service that I found the courage to face my challenges. 

 



In conclusion, my relationship with Jesus is the compass by which I navigate the world. It shapes my values, influences my perspective, and inspires my actions. Through mission trips, outreach programs, and personal encounters, I am dedicated to sharing the transformative power of Jesus' love. As I look to the future, I am filled with excitement for the adventures that await and the opportunities to serve. I am reminded that life is fleeting, and it is my heartfelt desire to live each day in a way that honors Jesus and brings me one step closer to the joy and tearless existence promised in heaven.

chapters.name: Community Work
chapters.details:
As I reflect on my journey with community work, I am filled with a sense of fulfillment and purpose. My relationship with the Old Folks Home, a cornerstone of my service, began with my volunteering at AWWA. Monthly, I would visit, distributing fruits and sharing precious moments with the elderly residents. There are about 120 of them, each with their own stories and wisdom, and through them, I've learned the importance of staying strong and fit as I age.

I've witnessed the spectrum of human emotions in these halls. Once, two ladies, initially friends, quarreled over money, turning into enemies. It was a stark reminder of how conflicts can escalate and the importance of promoting harmony. I've always tried to be a peacemaker, encouraging forgiveness and reminding the residents that life is too short for petty disagreements. 

My efforts to foster unity extend to organizing fellowship gatherings, where we sing, share, and discuss the essence of happiness, love, and forgiveness. These moments are precious; they bring us together and remind us of the shared human experience. Christmas is especially memorable. We decorate the hall, sing carols, and share stories of transformation and redemption. Once, we even had ex-convict singers perform, their testimonies of change touching everyone's hearts.

One of my most cherished experiences was visiting an elderly gentleman in his home. Our conversations about community work and life updates have deepened our bond, and it's a humbling reminder of the impact we can have on one another's lives. Despite my wanderlust, my commitment to serving others remains unwavering. The Old Folks Home has been a haven of learning and giving, and I intend to continue my service there. My faith guides me, and I strive to do things pleasing to God, for I believe my ultimate destination is with Him in heaven.



In conclusion I hope to inspire others to find their passion in service, to seek harmony and understanding, and to live a life filled with purpose. Whether it's through the simple act of distributing fruits or the deeper engagement of heartfelt conversations, every moment counts. And as I look to the horizon, ready to embark on new journeys, I know that the essence of my work in the community will always be a part of who I am. It's a legacy of love, faith, and service that I hope to leave behind, a testament to a life well-lived and a future filled with hope.

We decorate the hall, sing carols, and share stories of transformation and redemption. Once, we even had ex-convict singers perform, their testimonies of change touching everyone's hearts.

One of my most cherished experiences was visiting an elderly gentleman in his home. Our conversations about community work and life updates have deepened our bond, and it's a humbling reminder of the impact we can have on one another's lives. Despite my wanderlust, my commitment to serving others remains unwavering. The Old Folks Home has been a haven of learning and giving, and I intend to continue my service there. My faith guides me, and I strive to do things pleasing to God, for I believe my ultimate destination is with Him in heaven.



In conclusion I hope to inspire others to find their passion in service, to seek harmony and understanding, and to live a life filled with purpose. Whether it's through the simple act of distributing fruits or the deeper engagement of heartfelt conversations, every moment counts. And as I look to the horizon, ready to embark on new journeys, I know that the essence of my work in the community will always be a part of who I am. It's a legacy of love, faith, and service that I hope to leave behind, a testament to a life well-lived and a future filled with hope.

chapters.name: Singapore
chapters.details:
After my time in Malaysia, I was captivated by the vibrant city-state of Singapore. It wasn't long before the city's pulsating energy and remarkable efficiency became an integral part of my life. The warmth of its people, the rich tapestry of its cuisine, and the precision of its public transport system made me feel deeply connected to this place.

Singapore's cultural mosaic, with its Chinese, Malay, and Indian communities, is a testament to harmony and mutual respect. I revel in the festive spirit during holidays like Chinese New Year, Deepavali, Hari Raya Puasa, and Christmas. Singing "Silent Night" against the backdrop of Singapore's glittering skyline during Christmas time is a cherished tradition that brings back fond memories of the nativity story.

Now retired, my bond with Singapore continues to evolve. The transportation system is excellent. Travelling by Mrt and buses are convenient. Singapore is more than a backdrop to my life; it is the catalyst for my growth, both professionally and personally. It is a city of cultural richness and operational excellence that has left an indelible mark on my heart. Here, in this city that I proudly call home, I have found an unwavering sense of belonging. Its stable economy and good governance contribute to a happy and peaceful life for its residents.

When it comes to local cuisine, my favorite spot for Bak Kut Teh is Song Fa, known for its aromatic soup and succulent ribs. Nasi lemak, with its rich coconut rice, crispy ikan bilis, egg, chicken, and sambal chili, is another dish that keeps me coming back for more.

Singapore's robust healthcare system is another aspect my family and I have greatly benefited from. As citizens, we enjoy many subsidies in government hospitals, which are affordable and accessible. This is just one of the many ways Singapore's commitment to progress and innovation has directly improved our quality of life.

Singapore's convenience is unparalleled, with supermarkets and eateries open 24 hours. The city never sleeps, and neither does its charm. 

Singapore, with its ceaseless dynamism and endless opportunities, has been a smart choice for me. It's a place where I've never been bored, a city that always has something to offer, no matter the hour. As I continue to explore and cherish other memorable places in the world, Singapore remains the heart of my story, a home that has nurtured my growth and happiness.

chapters.name: Conclusion:Road Ahead
chapters.details:
As I am turning 70 with more grey hairs , I just want to look forward to a simple life .If  time permits I would like to travel to new horizons.

Yet, the road ahead is not solely about the allure of new horizons. It loops back to the cherished landscapes of my Malaysian heritage—Sungei Pelek, Kuala Lumpur, Kota Kinabalu—each a cherished chapter in the story of my life. These places are not just coordinates on a map; they are the emotional milestones that have shaped my heart. I am called to serve, to give back to the community. I envision my days enriched by contributing to old folks' homes, living a life that resonates with the divine. 

I am also blessed with a family that is a source of boundless gratitude. God has graced us with obedient children, a grandchild, and loving daughter-in-laws. My heart swells with thanks for the abundant protection, provision, and blessings showered upon my loved ones.

The road ahead may be tough and full of uncertainty . But I know who hold the future. May our God continue to guide , protect us in this journey.
